Chinese Salon Customers Think White Guy Can’t Understand Their Gossip…

I’m an Aussie construction worker and over 20years ago I spent two years learning mandarin at night school; then one day i swear to god, I randomly bumped into Jackie Chan on the street while he was filming a movie here in melbourne and I said “Jackie Chan! Ni hao ma! Wo xihuan ni Dian shi!” (Yeah yeah my pinyin is terrible and so is my mandarin lol) While wearing my construction hi-viz. and got a major double-take from him. He smiled and shook my hand and gave Me a big thumbs up. Wish I could’ve filmed that but it was before smart phones. Anyway I still like to order food in mandarin whenever I go to a Chinese restaurant because it makes everyone happy and that’s why I love your videos mate. Might try your app soon!

This was so fun to watch & I especially enjoyed watching the interactions between you and the unsuspecting customers, when you went from speaking in English (with an accent), to speaking in Mandarin, as well as some of the specific Fuzhou dialect. Brilliantly done, 

Thank you also for sharing the information about your language app at the beginning of your video. I'm super interested,  myself.  I feel, based merely on what I've seen & read, that the app may be a good fit for learners such as myself, who both prefer & rely on audio feedback/correction, in addition to the visuals of learning _(for example: seeing a word on the screen at the same time an audio pronunciation is being played helps me remember the sound that certain letter combinations may make in any given language).

I have always wanted to learn another language and life had been very difficult for me in the last years, so I stopped really even thinking about it. I met some very nice people that work at the gas station near my house that speak nepali and I told them I would learn it. 

I never got around to it because of life happening, but I watched alot of your videos last night for the first time and I decided first of all because of the reactions of chinese people to your mandarin that I would like to learn that, as well as Nepali. 

I appreciate your videos very much. I also work with alot of people from different places and one of my closest team is from nepal. That is what makes it such a great choice to start with. When you have real things every day to practice and talk about just doing work could be very good.

My cousin and I both tried to learn Japanese because we watched so much anime. We tried using Rosetta stone but the main problem was that it was a female voice... so we were both kinda doing "high pitched japanese" instead of what we should be sounding like. I also found out my name is exclusively a female name in Japan lol.

Ultimately we stopped because neither of us could agree on how to say H. He insisted it was like SH but without the S and whatever sound he was making was not matching the lady on the screen and I kept contending that SH without the H is H lol. Whoever was right, neither of our ears were hearing the same thing so we reached an empasse and gave up.
